column2: LEAD: WE already know as much about Ritchie Valens's brief life as we learn from ''La Bamba,'' the film biography that traces his early love of music, his dizzying rise to stardom and his tragic death in a plane crash. We know these things less specifically from Valens's own story than as conventions of this film and others like it, among them ''The Buddy Holly Story'' and ''Sweet Dreams,'' the biography of Patsy

LEAD: A 27 year old man who once served a prison term for manslaughter and was described by the authorities as ''extremely dangerous'' escaped from a dormitory-style jail annex on Rikers Island early yesterday by breaking a hole through the wall of the prefabricated structure, the police said.

LEAD: The reporter for a national magazine must have thought he had stumbled on one of the baseball stories of the year - a 10-minute clubhouse interview with Don Mattingly in Minneapolis revealing an egotistical, boastful, obnoxious streak that the Yankee first baseman had never shown before.

LEAD: Two pianists, Eddie Palmieri and Hilton Ruiz, are leading groups in a Latin-jazz double bill tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

LEAD: How to stay cool as hot air settles in for the summer on New York's streets? Some beat the heat the old-fashioned way: they churn it, fans in hand. Fans of fanning can easily find precursors. Madame Butterfly did it with delicacy. Karl Lagerfeld, the French designer, is so enamored of his fans that he carries them constantly and has even used them as the logo on his designs.
LEAD: In the streets of Borough Park, they now debate the strange and mysterious meaning of George Paskesz's death.

LEAD: Camille Roman, a social worker from Queens, did not believe Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North when he testified before the Iran-contra panel last week. So she sent a telegram of support to Senator Daniel K. Inouye.
LEAD: The Xerox Corporation's profits rose 26.2 percent in the second quarter, as results improved in both business products and financial services, the company said today.
LEAD: Archbishop Adolphe E. Proulx, a champion of the poor and oppressed, was found dead at his summer cottage on the St. Lawrence River Wednesday. He was 59 years old.

LEAD: Abercrombie & Fitch, the sporting goods store known for its sometimes exotic merchandise, will be sold by Oshman's Sporting Goods Inc. of Houston. An investor group headed by Michel Zelnik, former president of Bidermann Industries, will pay $30 million in cash and $20 million in junior subordinated notes.

LEAD: Bolstered by a new study showing that Sun Belt States lag well behind other regions of the country in their share of the Federal dollar, a coalition of Southern lawmakers vowed today to wield their legislative power to send more money southward.

He has accepted President Reagan's proposal to eliminate all medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles in Asia as well as in Europe. There is now no serious excuse for failure to resolve remaining differences.

LEAD: THE term ''painter-etcher'' was more than a genteelism distinguishing the ''fine'' from the commercial etcher. A coinage of the 1870's, it was also a reflection, if faint, of the growing interest in blending all the arts into one Wagnerian whole. Similarly, the American painter-etcher movement accomplished more than the estheticizing of the graphic medium.

LEAD: AN 11th-century Byzantine mosaic - removed from an Italian cathedral in the 1850's and rediscovered a year ago in a Welsh church - was bought for $427,152 this month at Sotheby's in London by a New York art dealer. The price for the work -which depicts the head of an apostle framed in a halo of gold - was a record at auction for a wall mosaic.

LEAD: With rookies, free agents and selected veterans scheduled to report to camp today, the Jets continued their frenzied bookkeeping yesterday by trading Johnny (Lam) Jones, their often-injured wide receiver, to the San Francisco 49ers for a ''high-to-middle'' but undisclosed 1988 draft choice. The Jets also signed their third-round choice, Onzy Elam, a 6-foot-2-inch, 225-pound linebacker from Tennessee State to a series of one-year contracts.

LEAD: Benjamin J. Kotsher, president of Communication Channels Inc., an Atlanta-based business magazine publishing company, died of pulmonary fibrosis Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Atlanta. He was 64 years old and lived in Atlanta.

LEAD: In what could prove to be New York's most extensive basement cleanup, the Transit Authority plans to remove old pipes and electrical lines, obsolete lighting fixtures and other hardware, misleading signs, dormant newsstands and many of the advertising billboards in an attempt to make many of the 463 subway stations look much the way they did when they were new.

LEAD: The Mayors of New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago and Kansas City, Mo., yesterday urged the head of the Federal Census Bureau to use statistical adjustments in the 1990 Census to avoid undercounting black and Hispanic citizens.

LEAD: The head of NBC News said yesterday that he was embarrassed that NBC failed to report that the General Electric Company was selling its consumer electronics business on its nightly news report Wednesday. General Electric is the parent company of the network.

LEAD: Kevin Ross, a former college basketball player who said he could barely read or write after four years at Creighton University, barricaded himself in his hotel room today until he was coaxed out by the educator who gave him a second chance.

LEAD: The Communications Satellite Corporation said today that Marcel P. Joseph is stepping down as president of the telecommunications company, which earlier this month sold off all but two of its unregulated businesses.

LEAD: A 35-year-old Hispanic businesswoman has been elected to the Alamogordo City Commission, apparently assisted by a new system intended to help members of minority groups win public office.
LEAD: The Senate approved a bill today that is designed to protect the health benefits of retired workers whose companies enter bankruptcy proceedings.

LEAD: In his second day of testimony yesterday at the Congressional hearings in Washington on the Iran-contra affair, George P. Shultz faced further questioning about high-level policy making. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from his testimony.

LEAD: A utility that has sunk $2 billion into the stalled Seabrook nuclear power plant risks becoming America's first public electric utility to file for bankruptcy protection since the Depression. The Public Service Company of New Hampshire acknowledged in a report that its Wall Street financing had dried up and that finding an alternative would be extremely difficult before its cash runs out by the end of the year.

LEAD: Ken O'Brien, the Jets' quarterback, did not follow the schedule and report to training camp last night, a team spokesman said. O'Brien, entering the final year of a $1.6 million, four-year contract that he signed after being a 1983 first-round draft choice, is reportedly seeking about $1 million a year.
LEAD: Indian and Sri Lankan officials said today that separatist Tamil guerrillas had ''agreed in principle'' to a proposal that could end a bitter four-year ethnic conflict in Sri Lanka.

LEAD: In a rare twist of nature, a massive, shifting sand bar has paralyzed traffic on the Mississippi River, stalling hundreds of barges here with millions of tons in cargo in a nautical gridlock on the nation's busiest inland waterway.

LEAD: Boxing Bugner Wins in Australia: Joe Bugner took another giant step in his bid to challenge for the World Boxing Council heavyweight title when he scored a unanimous 10-round decision over Greg Page last night in Sydney. LEAD: Although Secretary of State George P. Shultz has received a favorable response from most legislators at the Iran-contra hearings, one Congressman challenged his conduct during yesterday's session.
LEAD: When the detonation of a mine sent a shock wave through an American convoy in the Persian Gulf today, there were no American minesweepers anywhere in the region.

LEAD: Part of the fun of each Superman film has always been that opening credit crawl, with its hilariously grandiose lettering and its stately pace. In ''Superman IV: The Quest for Peace,'' which opened yesterday at the New Carnegie and other theaters, the credits zip by in a shaky manner, trailed by billows of unsightly glitter.

LEAD: Preliminary results of a study of 444 Vietnam veterans who may have been exposed to the herbicide Agent Orange show that very few veterans have unusually high levels of dioxin, the potentially harmful chemical in the herbicide, researchers said today.

LEAD: Entertainment Marketing Inc. said that it ''has a good-faith intention to acquire 15 percent'' of Crazy Eddie Inc.'s 30.9 million shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Entertainment said that it was seeking permission under Federal antitrust laws to raise its stake to 15 percent from its present 5.5 percent.
LEAD: Bond prices fell again in light trading yesterday following the report of a stronger-than-expected 2.6 percent rise in the nation's second-quarter gross national product.
LEAD: Better-paying private jobs are luring away Federal workers in the cleanup of the nation's worst toxic waste dumps, and the turnover is slowing down the project, Congressional investigators say.

LEAD: A tank of sulfuric acid exploded Thursday at a chemical plant here, sending the 20,000-gallon container rocketing off its stand and killing two people and injuring at least three others.

It opened a two-night engagement Wednesday at Sounds of Brazil to a star-struck, predominantly Senegalese audience.

LEAD: THE castlelike stationhouse of the old 18th Police Precinct has long been a landmark on Fourth Avenue in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn. When it was vacated in 1970, deterioration of the 1892 building accelerated, and a fire in 1980 seemed to have sealed its fate. But the Sunset Park School of Music purchased it at auction in 1984, after landmark designation, and it is now painstakingly collecting the $2.5 million it needs to restore the building.

LEAD: THE jazz age is a bountiful source of inspiration for the current generation of fashion followers. Loose, low-waisted dresses, antique lace collars and T-strap shoes are among the signatures of the flapper era that have made made the transition to the late 1980's. But probably no touch from that era makes as vivid an impression as the new straw hats, with wide or narrow brims, worn low on the head, echoing the 1920's.

LEAD: THE insider-trading scandal has hit a lull. In Washington, the Securities and Exchange Commission is starring only in the confirmation hearings of David S. Ruder, President Reagan's nominee to replace John S. R. Shad as S.E.C. chief.

LEAD: WHEN the restaurant at the Inn at Mill River opened in Stamford some two years ago, its esthetically delightful presentations, inventive menu and culinary finesse merited an enthusiastic three stars.

LEAD: An ambitious plan to link parks, museums and other cultural and recreational centers in Brooklyn and Queens by way of a 40-mile bicycle and pedestrian path is one step closer to becoming a reality.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: THE case in Federal court boiled down to this: Was the Government violating the rights of wild horses?
LEAD: As portrayed in local newspapers and in television newscasts until the end of June, South Korea was a land of ribbon-cuttings, official visits, sports, harmony and not much else.

LEAD: After a steady trickle of fraud in academic science, there now comes a serious case of misrepresented data. Charles J. Glueck, of the University of Cincinnati, reported that children can effectively be fed a low-cholesterol diet to prevent heart disease. But the prescription may be false: a university committee found that the study was based on data that ''barely existed.

LEAD: ALIVE AND WRITING: Interviews With American Authors of the 1980s. Conducted and edited by Larry McCaffery and Sinda Gregory. (University of Illinois, $22.50.) As presented here, the reflections of Ann Beattie, Ursula Le Guin, Thomas McGuane, Edmund White and nine others offer an intriguing but one-sided view of American writing today.

LEAD: ON July 18, Jamie Towers in the Castle Hill section of the Bronx became the 59th housing project in New York State's Mitchell-Lama program to reach its 20th anniversary and thereby become eligible to leave the middle-income government subsidized housing program.

LEAD: Twenty-five days after it started and one day before it officially finishes, the Tour de France came down today to a two-man duel between the only riders who still had a chance to win the bicycle race.

LEAD: Elizabeth Gorham Hanna, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Hanna Jr. of Old Chatham, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Williams Morss, a son of Shelley Christine Morss of Concord, Mass., and Charles Anthony Morss Jr. of Lincoln, Mass., at the Church on the Hill of the United Church of Christ in Lenox, Mass.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Last year the Japanese architect Masayuki Kurokawa got together with two designers, Issey Miyake and Shiro Kuramata, to upgrade mass-market watch designs. Two of Mr. Kurokawa's designs are the first in the collection. The Rabit has subtle raised lines instead of numbers. The Delhi has a more industrial look.
LEAD: I AM SITTING on an aluminum chair under a beach umbrella that's stuck in the hole of a large wooden spool that once held a roll of wire.
LEAD: Bob Brenly, who hit a home run earlier in the game, had a run-scoring, two-out single in the seventh inning to give the San Francisco Giants a 5-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

LEAD: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court is undergoing treatment for prostate cancer and has an ''excellent'' prognosis, the Mayo Clinic said last week. The clinic reported a ''small and localized recurrence'' of cancer that led to surgery 10 years ago. The clinic described the treatment as ''not incapacitating,'' and a Court spokeswoman said Justice Blackmun was preparing for the next term.

LEAD: When I read Edward Harper's article ''All Eyes on Her'' (About Men, May 24), and the subsequent letters to the editor regarding that article (June 21), I understood how he felt and I identified with him.

LEAD: President Reagan today assailed a bill passed by the House to protect the elderly against the costs of catastrophic illness, saying it would impose a heavy new tax on the elderly and could bankrupt the Medicare trust fund.

LEAD: Not long ago women's groups distributed buttons reading ''59 cents,'' the amount that working women were paid, on average, for each dollar earned by a man. The good news and the bad news, according to a study issued last week by a Congressional group, is that the figure is now 68 cents.

LEAD: Flip Tax Question: I recently sold my one-bedroom co-op apartment and have bought another apartment in the same building. The co-op board informed me that I would have to pay a flip tax on the sale of my apartment. Since I am purchasing another apartment in the same building I want to know if it is legal to charge me this tax.

LEAD: In a new 162-unit condominium development planned for 76 acres in Kent, N.Y., just north of Carmel in Putnam County, the developer has slipped a covenant in the deed saying that eight of the acres, zoned for commercial use, may never be touched. ''We could have built a strip center or an office building, but this will insulate the community and protect its serenity,'' said Jack C.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: A PARADOX OF TELEVISION IS THIS: IT is intrinsically more balanced, fair and open than print, but unlike print, it can determine its own agenda. Television is one on one: Someone speaks; we react, and no one gets in the way. Obviously, this is more straightforward than print, where readers must rely on reporters.

LEAD: Penny Aleen Levitt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Levitt of Mountainside, N.J., was married yesterday to David McDowell Bennett, a son of Mrs. Alfred M. Bennett of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Dr. Bennett. The Rev. Elmer Talcott, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Stronghold Mansion on the campus of the Gill-St.

LEAD: IN THEORY, THE GRATEFUL Dead are irresistible. Here's what they do: They roll into town, set up, play for about four hours and move on. What they play depends on the six musicians' moods. It might be a song they just finished, anything they've recorded in the last 20 years, an affectionate version of something by Buddy Holly or by Merle

LEAD: Jim Hightower, the Texas Agriculture Commissioner known for populist politics and a razor-sharp wit, visited New York last week to promote the cuisine of the Lone Star state. Mr. Hightower dropped by City Hall for a brief talk with the Mayor.

LEAD: PAINTED IN BLOOD: Understanding Europeans. By Stuart Miller. (Atheneum, $17.95.) The premise of this short and breezy book is that Europeans differ from Americans because of their ''background of collective violence'' - their history, according to Stuart Miller, is ''painted in blood.'' ''We must think,'' he suggests, ''of a vast South Bronx of a continent, repeatedly devastated not for ten or twenty years but, as men experience time, forever.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Benson of Kings Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Hilary Benson, to Peter Norman Ruben, the son of Mrs. Mark Olivetti of Rutherford, N.J., and Harris Ruben of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The couple plan to marry in November.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE WORD for Lawrence Taylor's book is not ''controversial.'' The word is ''confessional,'' but without much repentance.
LEAD: Peasants demanding land reform and crowds of people working for landowners have battled with machetes in a clash that may have killed 50 and wounded many more, radio stations reported today.

LEAD: I DON'T THINK I CAN do it,'' I said to the assistant producer, Cindy Wall. She had called me from Washington to say, ''We would like to film you in the room where Scott Fitzgerald died.'' She was speaking for The Film Company in the nation's capital, a maker of documentaries about American writers who lived and died in the 19th and 20th centuries.
LEAD: Billy Williams, the Sweet Swinger from Whistler, Ala., and the iron man of the Chicago Cubs, won't have to worry about his place in the baseball Hall of Fame after this weekend.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Roy Dikeman Chapin Jr. of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., and Geyserville, Calif., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Lita Bisbee Wickser, to John Gerard Toland, a son of Mrs. John M. Toland of Toms River, N.J., and the late Mr. Toland. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: Before we judge whether the Knicks are back on track, let's give Rick Pitino a chance to do what he has done everywhere he has been: 1. Win. 2. Produce a team that plays an exciting, fun-to-watch game of basketball.

LEAD: MORE than 10 years after the fighting ended, a memorial to Vietnam veterans is being constructed in Danbury. The memorial is a statue of an infantryman carrying a Vietnamese child in one arm and his rifle in another.

LEAD: AN EASILY overlooked exhibition space among the tourist attractions in one of New Jersey's neighboring cities - historic Bethlehem, Pa. - is a gallery in the Luckenbach Mill. which houses the local Visitors Center.

LEAD: For the last several years residents near Laurel Canyon Park, a four-acre patch of green in an affluent area of Los Angeles, have been divided over who should take precedence: playing children or unleashed dogs.
LEAD: PERMANENT CONNECTIONS By Sue Ellen Bridgers. 264 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95. (Ages 12 and up)

LEAD: I am writing to bring to your attention several factual errors in the June 7 article entitled ''Suit Challenges Welfare Rent'' by Sharon L. Bass. Ms. Bass states that ''a single person receives $157.72 a month for shelter and $251 for food, utilities and clothing.'' In fact, in the city of Bridgeport they would receive a maximum of $118 a month for rent for an unfurnished apartment, and a maximum of $310 a month for a furnished apartment.

LEAD: Like other professional sports stars, top-flight racing stars are as much businessmen as athletes. Long gone are the days of the happy-go-lucky, greasy-fingernailed vagabonds closing bars in the early morning hours and then racing off their hangovers to the accompaniment of high-decibel exhaust notes.

LEAD: The engagement of Jennifer Hartman Travers to Mark Stephen Aramburu has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Michael K. Travers of Ridgewood, N.J. The future bridegroom is the son of Anthony Aramburu of North Collins, N.Y., and Mrs. Ronald Stulak of Blasdell, N.Y. An Aug.

LEAD: It seems as if private initiative in Pakistan extends even to securing materials for, and producing, nuclear bombs. That at least is what Pakistan would have the U.S. believe, in the latest and most creative of a string of alibis designed to render palatable a decade-old addiction to secret nuclear pursuits.

LEAD: It is fitting that the Buffalo Bill Historical Center, an eclectic center of artworks and memorabilia inspired by the Western landscape and culture, is in Cody, Wyo. For just out the door of the building, and a short drive up the road, the expansive, dun-colored Western plains rise up to meet the heavily timbered, wildlife-rich Yellowstone National Park.

LEAD: FAX, or facsimile transmission, by which documents containing both pictures and text can be transmitted practically instantaneously over telephone lines, has come to the world of personal computing.
LEAD: For the next 12 months, amateur athletic competition in the United States will intensify as thousands of athletes compete for precious few berths on the 1988 Olympic team.

LEAD: AT a circus, one act always wows the audience: an unsteady character teeters and stumbles his way across the high wire. Thursday's concert by the Replacements, at the Beacon Theater, had that kind of slapstick suspense.
LEAD: ONE of Frank N. Piasecki's big ideas, the Helistat - part airship, part helicopter - went up in flames a year ago this month. Another idea has risen from the ashes.

LEAD: Two of three new apartment buildings rising on the west side of Union Square, collectively called Carlyle Court, will soon be teeming with college students rather than the young professionals increasingly drawn to that neighborhood.

LEAD: Katherine Oliver Tobin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Henry deYoung Tobin of Hillsborough, Calif., was married yesterday to George Carroll Whipple 3d, the son of Mrs. George Carroll Whipple Jr. of New York and the late Mr. Whipple. Judge William Newsom of the California Court of Appeals officiated at the Burlingame Country Club in

LEAD: Flight of Thunder Bird THE ROAR of an aircraft's engines over Teterboro Airport earlier this month was cause to stop and notice, even though such sounds are commonplace there. But the sounds were distinct and reminiscent of another era, a time when aircraft leaving Teterboro for Europe fought a raging war in addition to poor weather.

LEAD: The National Democratic Party of President Hosni Mubarak, in which the several contending factions range from socialists to free-wheeling capitalists, has increasingly begun to embrace Islamic symbols.

LEAD: Unlike architecture, much in interior design history is fleeting and unrecorded. In contrast to architects, decorators have not traditionally written philosophical treatises on their work -perhaps, C. Ray Smith suggests, because they've never had a philosophy. Then there is the matter of pioneering female decorators like Ruby Ross Wood who, owing to vanity, never divulged their birth dates; all this makes the historian's job trying, at best.

LEAD: When President Reagan called last month for the creation of an advisory panel on AIDS, White House officials made it clear that they felt no obligation to appoint a homosexual. To the dismay of gay rights advocates, Gary L. Bauer, the President's domestic policy adviser, said he ''would be very surprised if an Administration opposed to making appointments on the basis of race or sex would agree to make an appointment based on bedroom habits.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: No, the Knicks are not back on track. Two things must still happen. First, each player must decide that he is coming to Madison Square Garden not to play a basketball game, but to win a basketball game. Second, Gulf and Western must sell the Knicks to a group of individuals who know and love the game of basketball.
LEAD: BECAUSE it is so versatile, chicken is the most popular meat for summer cooking.

LEAD: The boys' choir of St. Thomas Church will soon have a new boarding school in which to practice its Kyrie eleisons, far larger and more elaborate than the old one on West 55th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. The 15-story structure, at 202 West 58th Street off Seventh Avenue, designed by Buttrick, White & Burtis of Manhattan and almost finished, grew out of a real estate deal between the church and Fisher Brothers, a
LEAD: THE Giants, who won Super Bowl XXI six months ago, will open their training camp tomorrow under a cloud.

LEAD: Key members of Congress, including Republicans who favor United States military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, say they do not share the Reagan Administration's view that the Iran-contra hearings have improved the outlook for continued aid.
LEAD: When the contents of the Pussy Cat Lounge, a strip joint, were auctioned here several weeks ago, the past and future of the city's adult entertainment zone were equally on display.

LEAD: IN THE LONG RUN. By N. J. Crisp. (Viking, $16.95.) Competent thrillers may be a dime a dozen in the world of figurative speech, but in the airport bookshop they cost considerably more. That's why most of us frequent fliers look for something beyond the swift plot and pungent dollops of sex and violence that are standard in the genre.
LEAD: EARLY REAGAN By Anne Edwards. Illustrated. 617 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $21.95.
LEAD: THIS is a war story, a tale of the battle that faces Long Islanders each summer as battalions of pinkish-red jellyfish take over our bays.

LEAD: AT THIS LATE DATE IN OUR musical history, interesting new compositions can come from any source, conventionally classical or otherwise. Especially in that shifting landscape formerly dubbed ''downtown'' music, meant to separate it from stiffer, more formal forms of Establishment contemporary composition, genre distinctions mean next to nothing.
LEAD: Mexico has become the hub for the smuggling of millions of dollars worth of rare and often endangered wildlife into the United States.

LEAD: THE sun beat down on Pam Glick of Manhattan last weekend as she tried to push her bike through sand drifts several feet deep, once a paved portion of Dune Road. Only the week before, Westhampton residents had been allowed back on the oceanfront road, closed since November because of severe erosion.

LEAD: The article misses the point of why there's a shortage. After interviews of several hospital administrators, their opinion is passed along that the hospital nurse shortage is due to declining nursing school enrollments. Those declining enrollments, however, are the symptom, not the cause: The shortage is being caused by the administrators themselves.

LEAD: Heartened by the movement toward democracy in the Philippines and South Korea, the United States was doing its bit last week to loosen yet another military leader's grip on power. Administration officials said all aid to Panama had been suspended in an effort to pressure Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who controls Panama's military and its Government.

LEAD: Vietnam: Legacies - Volume 7 Chief correspondent, Stanley Karnow; producer, Elizabeth Deane; executive producer, Richard Ellison. Sony Video Software. 60 minutes. $19.95. The legacies of the 10-year war in Vietnam - longer than World Wars I and II together - are illustrated in the final film in the series, ''Vietnam: A Television History,'' originally presented by WGBH-Boston as a 13-hour series on public television.

LEAD: For years, I have been amazed at the growing popularity of exorbitantly priced attached and semiattached development homes, marketed under euphemistic labels such as ''planned communities'' and ''townhomes,'' when they are basically glorified Levittowns, with no individuality or privacy.

LEAD: THE Internal Revenue Service is putting the pressure on taxpayers to settle continuing disputes. In late May, the I.R.S. began a formal program to clear up a backlog of tax-shelter cases by offering 75,000 investors a one-shot chance to settle. And in all cases, taxpayers are finding it is increasingly expensive to fight: Last year the penalty for substantial understatement of tax jumped to 25 percent of the tax owed from 10 percent.
LEAD: THE LAW OF SUPPLY AND demand seems to have lost some of its teeth. A glut of CD's is just around the corner, yet no price cut is in sight.

LEAD: AS usual, any performing situation in the great outdoors of Central Park has its special dimension. The weekly dance concert presented by Creative Time as part of Central Park's SummerStage series was provided with extra drama Friday night when lightning accompanied three pieces by Ann Carlson.

LEAD: With relations with the United States at one of the lowest points in years, the Cuban Government is charging in an extensive television and newspaper campaign that many American diplomats here have been spying and plotting to assassinate President Fidel Castro.

LEAD: Marian Chatfield-Taylor's article [ ''The Sorry Success of a Part-Time Teacher,'' Opinion page, June 21 ] summoned still-vivid memories of two experiences I had with Norwalk Community College three years ago:

LEAD: The engagement of Cecelia Lodi Kaufmann to David Lapham Mead has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. John Hollis Kaufmann of Somerset, Bermuda. Mr. Mead is the son of Stephen Mead of Boston and Mrs. Carl Pescosolido of Ipswich, Mass. A November wedding is planned.

LEAD: IN the old days, the only way to find out how many people were watching a network television show was to check the Nielsens. CBS, ABC and NBC, along with advertising agencies and a few consumer products companies, paid tidy sums for access to the Nielsen ratings. They used them to decide which shows would live to see another season and how much commercials on those shows would cost.
LEAD: WITH the legislative races drawing closer, some lawmakers are talking about trying to limit the amount of money that candidates can spend this year.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver North during game Friday night at Memorial Stadium in Baltimore. He sat in a special box near the Orioles' dugout and watched the Orioles extend their winning streak to 10. (AP)

LEAD: Merchant vessels in the Persian Gulf reported a new sighting of mines today, off the Saudi Arabian coast and south of the area where a Kuwaiti tanker flying the American flag and escorted by American warships struck a mine on Friday.
LEAD: The Week in Business on July 12 incorrectly described Alan Greenspan's affiliation with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. He was a director.

LEAD: EARLIER in the season, Mike Scott of Houston and Rick Rhoden of the Yankees headed the major leagues' Scuffball Suspects list. The scrutiny of those two successful pitchers has eased, but the subject of illegal pitches is never far from the surface. Probably with good reason. One pitcher who admits privately to doing funny things with baseballs said each pitching staff has at least one pitcher who scuffs, cuts or moistens some of the balls he throws.
LEAD: CUZCATLAN Where the Southern Sea Beats. By Manlio Argueta. Translated by Clark Hansen. 255 pp. New York: Aventura/Vintage Books. Paper, $7.95.
LEAD: Lou Whitaker's two-out home run in the 10th inning gave the Detroit Tigers a 5-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians today.
LEAD: In a despairing 42-year-old letter that has just come to light, Czeslaw Milosz, the Nobel Prize poet, deplored what he saw as insensitivity in his fellow Poles.

LEAD: Sentiment on the Iran-contra committees swung during the week from general skepticism and disapproval of Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter's final testimony on Tuesday to acceptance and praise of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's candor at week's end. Highlights of the week's developments follow.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: IT'S 10:15 ON A TUESDAY MORNING. I'm at my desk, dictating out a stack of X-rays, when the phone rings. It's Carol, our C.T. (computed tomography) scan technologist. ''Dr. Shragg, we're ready to do the biopsy.'' ''I'll be right over,'' I tell her. A woman has a tumor in her pancreas. Her internist has asked me, the radiologist, to do a needle biopsy.
LEAD: The Boston Licensing Board has adopted a rule prohibiting liquor licenses for business and professional clubs that discriminate in their membership.

LEAD: JOHN ANDREWS has become accustomed to new customers at the J&J Bait and Tackle Shop along the Clinton waterfront asking him the whereabouts of the owner. That is not surprising, because John is 12 years old and, at 4 feet 11 inches, can barely see over the counter.
LEAD: THE Salvadoran guerrillas are practicing what they call ''prolonged popular war'' with a vengeance, as the country slides into its eighth year of civil conflict.
LEAD: The advance contingent of the largest collection of football hopefuls ever invited to a Jet training camp began the countdown to the 1987 season today.

LEAD: The recent article ''Interfaith Bridals: Chapels in Demand'' gives the impression that there is a ''clerical stable'' of clergy - including many rabbis who will officiate at interfaith weddings. That is not the reality on Long Island.

LEAD: Singers and instrumentalists seldom venture outdoors alone. The weather (when right) can be an excellent accomplice, but the haphazards of an uncontrolled environment - plus the problem of hearing one's self properly without surrounding walls and ceiling - remain very real.

LEAD: Amityville $178,000 217 South Bay Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; family room, fireplace; 2d 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old ranch on property; taxes $2,700. Bellport $135,000 36 New Jersey Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 26-year-old ranch; basement, 2-car garage, walk to stores; taxes $1,500.
LEAD: The Government, plagued by a 4-year civil war, today declared a nationwide state of emergency and said it was necessary because of a rapidly deteriorating economic situation.
LEAD: Moving to crush a potential rival, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, expelled his former Finance Minister, Vishwanath Pratap Singh, from the ruling Congress Party last week.

LEAD: IF, AS PHILIP JOHNSON ONCE said, ''The first law of architecture is 'get the job!' '' the first law of American museum directorship is ''get along with the board of trustees!'' You may be scholar, connoisseur and master of forward planning. You may run a tight ship, with the love and support of your staff.

LEAD: Hispanic children around the country are increasingly attending segregated schools, and New York is the most segregated state of all for the students, according to a study of Federal data on school enrollment by researchers at the University of Chicago.

LEAD: WE PROFESSIONALS GO TO the movies ready to pay hawklike attention to anything that happens on the screen. It's the result of years of on-the-job training, and it's also force of habit after a while. In a perfect world, this would be the best way for anyone to watch films, but the world is not perfect, as is demonstrated weekly by each new batch of summer releases.
LEAD: Max Fortunoff, founder and chairman of the New York specialty stores that bear his name, died yesterday at his home in Old Westbury, L.I., after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: The article ''Shortage of Nurses Vexes Hospitals'' [ June 28 ] did an admirable job of presenting the shortage of nurses in Long Island hospitals. However, several inaccuracies created a distorted picture of the Molloy College nursing department.
LEAD: THERE IS A CERTAIN POETIC justice in Ann Magnuson's being invited to perform at Alice Tully Hall.

LEAD: Betty Holland Ward of New Orleans has announced the engagement of her daughter Elizabeth Holland Ward to Scott Preston Spector, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Spector of St. Petersburg, Fla. The couple plan to marry Aug. 22.

LEAD: Dawn stirs gently here through bamboo groves and waist-high fields of rice. With languid ease, the pale cloud boas draping nearby hilltops unravel as a solitary farmer shooshes a water buffalo along a gravel path still damp with dew.

LEAD: EACH YEAR IN WEST BER-lin, the Theatertreffen (Theater Discoveries), a three-week festival of stage productions culled from theaters throughout German-speaking countries, offers a reliable, if unofficial, barometer of the type of drama currently popular in this part of the world. The event includes 12 major productions: new versions of classic works; foreign plays, old and new, and original works that have been judged important enough to be invited to this prestigious festival.

LEAD: Administration officials say the Nicaraguan Government has almost completed work on the longest airfield in Central America, which they fear the Soviet Union might use to extend its reconnaisance missions in this hemisphere.

LEAD: HARVEST OF BITTERSWEET. By Patricia Penton Leimbach. Illustrated by Jack Homesley. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) Patricia Penton Leimbach has a double career: alongside her husband of more than 35 years she has operated End o' Way, a grain and vegetable farm near Vermilion, Ohio; her column, Country Wife, selections from which make up a portion of ''Harvest of Bittersweet,'' is published in the Elyria, Ohio, Chronicle-Telegram.

LEAD: THE MAN WHO ROBBED THE PIERRE: The Story of Bobby Comfort. By Ira Berkow. (Atheneum, $17.95.) It was a caper out of a Hollywood production of the 1930's: five dinner-jacketed thieves walk into a deluxe Manhattan hotel, handcuff 19 employees and guests and walk out with more than $10 million in jewels and cash.

LEAD: Groundcovers Morris Video. 2730 Monterey Street 105 Torrance, Calif. 90503. (800)843-3606 60 minutes. $19.95. Northeastern gardeners should keep their own climate in mind while viewing this video. It was filmed in the Pacific Northwest, where just about anything will grow. Ed Hume, a TV personality and garden columnist for The Seattle Times, is a knowledgeable host.

LEAD: ON THE STAGE OF THE MAXIM GORKY House of Culture, beneath a red banner urging all good citizens of the Soviet Union to ''fulfill the decisions of the 27th Party Congress,'' Anatoly Krupnov, the lead singer of Black Obelisk, is howling out the lyrics to ''Disease.'' Bare-chested except for a guitar and chain, he struts through a cloud of artificial smoke.

LEAD: SILHOUETTES Does the name Etienne de Silhouette ring a bell? Only the last part, right? He was a controller general in the court of Louis XV who whiled away his retirement by cutting paper into landscapes and the shapes of people.

LEAD: What a nice, old-fashioned feeling amazement is. Here is Amos T. Root in 1905, describing ''the first circling flight ever made by a heavier-than-air machine.'' It is quoted in ''Wilbur and Orville: A Biography of the Wright Brothers'' (Knopf) by Fred Howard.
LEAD: ''As car sales grow weaker, it will take a lot of blood, sweat and tears on the cost-cutting side to maintain positive year-to-year comparisons.''

LEAD: OUR nation needs outstanding public schools. If we are to have them, we know that we need to attract talented, bright people to become teachers and administrators. But there is another fundamental need we often overlook. We need local townspeople to become involved. We need people who are willing to consider running for the local board of education.

LEAD: Sunbathers with their chairs at water's edge yesteday at Orchard Beach in the Bronx as the temperature rose, for the fifth time in the week, past 90 degrees to a record-high 95. Relief is due tomorrow. (NYT/Jim Wilson)
LEAD: THE fight is for the unified heavyweight title, and ordinarily that sort of matchup would be a hot ticket.
LEAD: A senior Government official said this week that the United States was bracing for Iranian attacks as a possible response to United States naval protection of Kuwaiti tankers.
LEAD: IN the eyes of Ralph Destino, chairman of Cartier Inc., not all gems are equal.

LEAD: For 50 years, the 2,096-mile Appalachian Trail has successfully dodged developers, fought off shopping centers and ducked highways from Maine to Georgia. Today hikers, trail volunteers and park officials gathered here to mark where the grand lady of American hiking trails began.

LEAD: I was pleased to read the article by Peggy McCarthy on state planning to increase the number of practicing nurses [ ''State Plan Urged to Gain Nurses,'' June 21 ] . That Dr. Norma Foreman Glasgow, the Commissioner of Higher Education, is calling for a broad and concerted effort to make the profession more attractive is encouraging.

LEAD: To the Editor: There is another very satisfactory alternative to traveling like a maharajah (''A Maharajah's Rail Journey in Rajasthan,'' Travel, June 28). I covered the same distances and sites and was free to wander by myself through palaces and markets, to stay in Agra to see the Taj in different lights and spend a few nights in the Lake Palace in

LEAD: MECHANICAL PUZ-zles - brain teasers that have engaged the curious for centuries -are the subject of an exhibition described by its organizers as the largest such historical survey ever assembled. The show, titled ''Puzzles Old and New: Head Crackers, Patience Provers and Other Tactile Teasers,'' opens today at the Hudson River Museum, where it remains through Sept.

LEAD: AFTER 42 years of living in Scarsdale, sending our four children through the entire Scarsdale school system, serving on committees that brought Scarsdale a swimming pool, ran the Christmas Carol Sing, helped a variety of funds hit that red ball at the top of the bar-chart poster, my wife and I had to face the cruel fact that a house that accommodated a family of six was now oversized for just two of us.

LEAD: MUSICAL MIX In its weekly concert series at the Bayard Cutting Arboretum, the Islip Arts Council usually showcases groups or individuals who specialize in one musical genre or another: classical, jazz or pop. But today One Alternative does it all. Composed of Mark Oppenlander and Peter Sittler, guitarists, and Jill Haley, oboist and English horn player - in itself an unusual mix - the trio blends classical, jazz, pop and folk to create a sound that one member calls ''acoustic fusion.

LEAD: IT took parliamentary contortions worthy of Rube Goldberg and the largest increase in state taxes in the nation's history, but Texas legislators last week finally adopted a spending and revenue blueprint that staved off financial chaos.
LEAD: A BUSINESS PARK under construction off Route 68 in Wallingford will offer tenants an optional service that they may share at a fraction of the cost to an individual buyer.
LEAD: The lives of millions of people in Asia, the Pacific and Latin America have been touched, deeply and for the better, by a turnaround in American foreign policy.
LEAD: Those free rolls of quarters now being used to lure the small gambler to Atlantic City may soon become a thing of the past.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo has promoted his chief spokesman with the press on most issues to the title of counselor and press secretary to the Governor, Mr. Cuomo's office announced today.

LEAD: It would be hard to think of two activities that are further apart, in terms of the alphabet, the equipment, the setting, or the type of effort, than bridge and yachting. The connection used to be the person of Harold Stirling Vanderbilt who brought contract bridge to the world via Newport, R.I., in the 1920's and was a triple winner of the America's Cup in the 1930's.

Congregational Church, Elizabeth Hamilton Kerney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Caldwell Kerney of Chittenden, Vt., was married yesterday to William Woodfill Zuehlke, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard William Zuehlke of Wakefield, R.I., by the Rev. Richard T. McDonnell.

LEAD: A heat wave gripping Turkey disturbed Kemal Pala, a gunsmith, so much that he bit his neighbor's howling dog, named Lassie, three times, the semi-official Anatolian News Agency said.The dog's owner, Mehmet Ahcioglu, reported the matter to the police in the western town of Biga.

LEAD: THEY were getting tired of stout-bodied skippers; they wanted satyrs and painted ladies, too. The five people recently searching a meadow at the Pequotsepos Nature Center in Mystic carefully recorded them all, each butterfly they could identify - numerous skippers, a few wood satyrs, a little painted lady, a swooping swallowtail and others, for a total of 64 individuals of 19 species.

LEAD: The championship is as good as theirs. All they have to do is transplant a pair of healthy knees onto Ewing (and maybe throw in a heart transplant in the process); trade Cartwright for a rebounding forward such as Karl Malone of Utah (dream on); convince Mark Jackson that he will not succumb to Pearl Washingtonitis (or rookie flop syndrome); teach Bernard King how to pass; hypnotize Kenny Walker into believing he can score 15 points game in and game out, and wait for the rookie coach, Rick Pitino, to win 60 games (he'll do it, too, but not in one season).

LEAD: NURSERY rhymes, Walter de la Mare wrote, ''call for as little in the way of introduction as . . . Santa Claus'' and are ''surer of perpetuity than the Pyramids of Egypt.'' They ''free the fancy, charm tongue and ear, delight the inward eye, and many of them are tiny masterpieces of verbal craftsmanship.

LEAD: When Gov. Michael S. Dukakis decided earlier this month to reverse a state policy that barred AIDS testing by insurance companies, he hoped his position would satisfy insurers while protecting the rights of homosexuals and lesbians.

LEAD: Despite the intense early campaigning of Democratic Presidential hopefuls, the percentage of Democrats undecided about their party's choice is growing, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows. It also found the Rev. Jesse Jackson still the only candidate with more than 10 percent support.

LEAD: In a formerly drab neighborhood in the eastern part of Vienna some photography addicts climb the utility poles or crouch on top of the cigarette vending machine at the corner of Keilgasse and Lowengasse, to get that special shot of the Hundertwasser House.

LEAD: ASTRANGER at the door is the catalyst for Ugo Betti's play ''Crime on Goat Island,'' translated from the Italian by Henry Reed. The Arena Players Repertory Theater, which is staging the Betti play at its Main Stage, is also offering ''Victim,'' by another Italian, Mario Fratti, at its Second Stage theater, and it too opens with a stranger at the door.

LEAD: Any number of New Jersey communities would covet a state center for the performing arts. Governor Kean's endorsement of downtown Newark as the site for the $200 million project therefore makes a strong statement. It demonstrates faith in a city more accustomed to cynicism, hope for a community more familiar with despair.

LEAD: To the Editor: As a native of Fall River, Mass., and a lover of Portuguese sweet bread (massa) and doughboys (malassadas), I greatly enjoyed reading ''Sweet Bread, Portuguese Style'' (Travel, May 17). Not mentioned was what I consider to be the best sweet bread bakery in New England - Faria's Bakery on Wickenden Street, near the Brown University campus in Providence.

LEAD: The prolonged war in Cambodia between Chinese-backed resistance forces and Vietnamese troops is giving Beijing the opportunity to strengthen and expand its influence in Southeast Asia, regional officials and others say.

LEAD: Since the end of Spanish colonial rule in 1898, many Philippine leaders have tried to bring about land reform and failed. Both the appeal and the pitfalls of redistribution were demonstrated last week when Corazon C. Aquino issued a decree aimed at breaking up some of the country's vast plantations and giving private plots to some of the millions of landless farm worker.

LEAD: A judge approved a final settlement today for the disposition of the estate of the artist Georgia O'Keeffe that includes the formation of a foundation to distribute many of her paintings to museums.

The Rev. John Livingston performed the ceremony at the United Church in Rowayton.

LEAD: When Jose Razo entered Harvard University in the fall of 1985, he seemed to blend in easily. Like most members of the freshman class, he had a bright, inquiring mind and had earned straight A's in high school.

The vessel pictured was not the original North Star belonging to the Commodore but one also named North Star that belonged to the Commodore's great-grandson, Cornelius
LEAD: In 1806, William L. Daggett built two big brick smokehouses on Central Wharf in Portland, Me. Sixty feet tall, their walls three feet thick, they were in continuous use until 1982.

LEAD: LAST Monday, the BancTexas Group, a beleaguered Dallas-based holding company, completed a huge financial restructuring that swung its net worth from a negative $98 million to a positive $90 million. The mechanics included a $150 million infusion of capital from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the forgiveness of substantial debt, and - perhaps most bewildering to the average investor - the use of a little-known financing technque called a rights offering, which enables existing stockholders to purchase additional shares at a discount from the market price.

LEAD: WHEN Warner Books, a power in paperback publishing, started publishing hardcover books a few years ago, it wanted to establish immediate credibility with booksellers. So, in an agreement drawn up on a napkin in a midtown Manhattan restaurant, it struck a deal with Random House, an old pro in the business.

LEAD: THE concept of Serious Fun!, the name of Lincoln Center's adventurously eclectic performing arts series at Alice Tully Hall, could not have been illustrated more perfectly than in its Wednesday night program, which brought together two quartets - one dancing, the other singing.

LEAD: Ten of New York State's most economically depressed communities had reason to cheer up last week. Governor Cuomo announced that the communities would be the first to be eligible for a broad set of tax breaks and other subsidies aimed at attracting new businesses.

LEAD: FOR a while we have had the extraordinary spectacle of two serious books that are highly critical of American life at the top of the nonfiction best-seller list, places usually held by humor, inspirational books and extraterrestrial experiences. As of this issue of The Book Review, Allan Bloom's ''Closing of the American Mind'' is in first place and E.

LEAD: ''GARBAGE BARGE'': Quite frankly, I got tired of reading about the six million pounds of garbage looking for a port. For months, government officials tried to find a solution to this problem. It really wasn't necessary to go down south to Louisiana or to exotic Belize to find the answer when it was much closer to home.
LEAD: Ruben Blades has a lot going for him, but in the history of salsa, he is just another talented name, not a creator (''Ruben Blades: Up From Salsa,'' by Anthony DePalma, June 21).

LEAD: HOPING to avert a potential employment crisis in county government, the county has begun a $469,394 job-compensation study that will include a review of all 9,000 county jobs and is designed to develop a more equitable pay program for employees.

LEAD: Gems, Baby Gifts And Figurines In celebration of its 60th year in New Rochelle, Talner Jewelers Roadside China (Roadside China was a store name in Yonkers for 30 years) is having an inventory sale through Saturday with 20 to 50 percent off regular prices. Diamond rings, pendants, necklaces, bracelets and earrings are included in the one-fifth off category and the half-price cuts change the tags on Piaget watches, costume jewelry and costume pierced earrings.

LEAD: Stamp issuing nations are flooding the philatelic market with hundreds of new issues. Alert worldwide collectors should exercise discretion with regard to exploitative material, but there are many interesting and worthy new issues.
LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev seems not to be above a light and mischievous touch in his new diplomacy. In this case, the target was the well-known phenomenon of Reagan Administration multispeak.

LEAD: The Salt Lake Trappers tonight established the longest winning streak in the history of organized baseball by winning their 28th consecutive game, 13-3 over the Pocatello Giants in the Pioneer League.

LEAD: ONE in six people in the state is older than 60. By the turn of the century, the proportion may be closer to one in four, and Connecticut will have more frail elderly - older than 85 - than any other New England state. Not surprisingly, therefore, issues of the elderly - and those who must care for them - are increasingly occupying the thoughts of public officials.

LEAD: The Problem With Rickey, a theme that created impatience in the Yankee clubhouse this week, may have moved several steps toward mutual understanding today. Unfortunately for Rickey Henderson and his Yankee teammates, the steps he took this afternoon were painful ones.

LEAD: Carol Vogel's article has confirmed one of my worst fears: it seems many of the affluent elite and, in many cases, the most powerful members of our society would rather soak in three-man Jacuzzis than confront the problems that exist beyond their meticulously maintained yards.

LEAD: Day Joanne Grymes and Allen Tison Keel Jr. were married yesterday at the Lamington Presbyterian Church in Bedminister, N.J. The Rev. Leon B. Gladdish performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. George Zabriskie 2d, an Episcopal priest and an uncle of the bride.

LEAD: At St. Edward the Confessor Roman Catholic Church in New Fairfield, Conn., Evelyn Edwards Kling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kling of Pittsford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Nicholas Andrew Gravante Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gravante of Brooklyn and New Fairfield. The Rev. Brian Gray performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Governor Kean has signed a bill making it more difficult for consumers to sue manufacturers when their products are suspected of being harmful. It shifts the burden of proof to the consumer, who now must show a safer design was feasible at the time the product was made. The new law also makes it more difficult to collect punitive damages, forcing the victim must prove ''actual malice'' on the part of the manufacturer, instead of ''reckless disregard.

LEAD: Molly Yard swept into office as president of the National Organization for Women last weekend with no shortage of large goals. The 70-ish Ms. Yard - she refuses to disclose her exact age - said NOW would, among other things, work to block the Supreme Court confirmation of Judge Robert H. Bork, attempt to win the Democratic Presidential nomination for Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, and muster a million marchers in support of an equal rights amendment to the Constitution.

LEAD: The engagement of Marsha Diamond to Dr. Marc Jeffrey Salzman, a son of Bobi Salzman of Vail, Colo., and Dr. Robert Salzman of Miami has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Diamond of Squirrel Hill, Pa. An October wedding is planned. Miss Diamond, a New York University graduate, is director of research at Camelot Entertainment Sales, a television advertising sales company in New York.
LEAD: In order for the Knicks to be back on track, the philosophy of upper-level management must change. Arthur Barron and Dick Evans, are you listening?

LEAD: Waquoit, the pride of Massachusetts racing, earned his fifth triumph without a defeat this year by scoring a three-length victory over Bordeaux Bob in the $415,800 Brooklyn Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

LEAD: Torrential rain flooded a river in northeastern Iran, killing at least 100 people and injuring 36 others, the official Iranian press agency reported today. The river Boojhan overflowed its banks Friday in Neishabour and nearby villages, the agency said. It quoted an official of the Red Crescent relief agency in Neishabour as saying intense rescue and relief operations were under way.

LEAD: Mayor Koch, who installed bicycle lanes in Manhattan in 1980 and then had to scrap them because they did not work, moved another step away last week from his one-time dream of turning New York into a cyclist's Beijing. In an effort to preserve the lives and limbs of pedestrians, he said, bicycles will be banned from Park, Madison and Fifth Avenues between 31st and 59th Streets from 10 A.M.

LEAD: Forrest E. Kendall, a professor emeritus of biochemistry at Columbia University, died of a heart attack yesterday in North Shore University Hospital, in Manhasset, L.I. He was 88 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

LEAD: Carol Vogel summed up the developments in building and suburban styles over the last several decades in a piece that was well researched, carefully thought out and very readable (''Clustered for Leisure: The Changing Home,'' June 28.) It's good to see The Times showing as much interest in the way Americans are living as it has always had in life styles of more exotic countries abroad.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Reis of Branford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Sarah Reis, to Matthew Dennis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Dennis of La Habra, Calif. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: NEW YORK INTELLECT A History of Intellectual Life in New York City, From 1750 to the Beginnings of Our Own Time. By Thomas Bender. 422 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

LEAD: THIS spring, a Russian nationalist group emerged from the political shadows to test Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign for ''glasnost,'' or openness, in Soviet society. For weeks, it seemed that all of Moscow was talking about the group, called Pamyat, which means memory, and its brazen public demonstrations.

LEAD: THE New York State Supreme Court has been asked to rule on whether anglers have a legal right to fish from a stretch of privately owned beach on East Island in the city of Glen Cove on Long Island.

LEAD: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, who died today in a rodeo accident in California, was a man of deeply contrasting shades who gained prominence in the Reagan Administration for his leadership on trade issues.
