LEAD: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Shelburne, Vt., yesterday, Anne Elizabeth Janson, a daughter of Ellen G. Janson of Shelburne and Dr. Richard H. Janson of South Burlington, Vt., was married to John Hunnewell Hasen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Hasen of New York and Greensboro, Vt.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Riccardo R. Puglielli of Rocky Hill, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lorella Puglielli, to Peter Henry Struzzi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruno P. Struzzi of Jericho, L.I. The wedding is to be April 16.
LEAD: A man was found stabbed to death early yesterday near West Drive in Central Park, the police said.

LEAD: The widening net of the Wedtech scandal has so far brought criminal indictments to 19 people associated with Government favors for the South Bronx military contractor. Last week, it encompassed another kind of action, a civil suit for $3.3 million, against E. Robert Wallach, a San Francisco lawyer and friend of Attorney General Edwin

LEAD: THE URGE TO CREATE JAZZ repertory ensembles has been bubbling up sporadically for the last 20 or 30 years. Orchestra U.S.A., the National Jazz Ensemble, the New York Jazz Repertory Company and the New York Jazz Repertory Orchestra have come and gone, although the American Jazz Orchestra is just completing its first year.

LEAD: MANY of the faces were different, but the sentiments remained the same. A proposed natural-gas pipeline got a cold reception last week as residents living in towns along the plan's new preferred route got their first major opportunity to air their views.

LEAD: SERGIU COMISSIONA'S first season as music director at the New York City Opera is if anything an exercise in variety. He is conducting three familiar items of widely differing style. The ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci'' double bill and Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' are two, and Friday night he dipped into French Romanticism and Gounod's ''Faust.

LEAD: RECENT headlines about the book industry have been telling tales of consolidations and mergers. But, quietly all across the land, small publishers have been springing up. Book publishing, after all, is easy to enter. All it takes is a title or two. But it is one thing to publish a book, another to get it into bookstores and into the hands of readers.

LEAD: We all live under the same sky, but each of us sees a different horizon. I am reminded of this after reading Pat Bard's excellent article, ''Mining Older Skill and Wisdom'' [ Opinion Page, June 28 ] .
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BILL BUCKNER, released by the Boston Red Sox, will sign with the Minnesota Twins next week if he clears waivers, according to his wife, Jody. The 37-year-old first baseman expects to be the Twins' designated hitter, The Minneapolis Star and Tribune reported yesterday.

LEAD: BARBARA KRUGER SAYS SHE didn't have to think twice about it. Sherrie Levine says it was like coming home. But the decisions by the two artists to join the high-powered Mary Boone Gallery has unsettled the downtown art world. The tremors filled the air in May, when the gallery showcased Kruger's photomontages for the first time, and they will reverberate anew in September, when an exhibition of

LEAD: MEMBERS of an organization of Russian traditionalists called Pamyat are motivated in part by a conspiracy theory that was invented in France almost a century ago. Like many reactionaries in the United States, followers of Pamyat equate satanism with rock music and relativism with evil, and they believe that Zionists are scheming with, of all people,
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Martha Miles was attempting, apparently, to be amusing in her article ''Too Close for Comfort'' [ About Long Island, June 28 ] . I found, however, nothing remotely humorous in the author's patent disregard for nature.

LEAD: The wedding of Frances Whelen Carey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Carey of Whitpain, Pa., to Donald Francis MacMaster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas J. MacMaster Jr. of Whitemarsh, Pa., took place yesterday. The Rev. Richard T. Hawkins performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Whitemarsh, assisted by the Rev.

LEAD: Madison $416,000 6 East Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, porch, 2-car garage; taxes $4,867. Randolph $146,000 8 Elm Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2 bath, 28-year-old split level; full basement, family room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,062.

LEAD: HAPPY HOUR By Alan Shapiro. 45 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. Cloth, $16. Paper, $7.95. FORESEEABLE FUTURES By William Matthews. 50 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $8.95. THE END OF BEAUTY By Jorie Graham. 99 pp. New York: The Ecco Press.

LEAD: JOSHUA BELL has a straight-on, modest style that reveals his Midwestern roots. His playing is neither coy nor self-aggrandizing, his sound is neither glossy nor slick. You can tell he thinks about how to shape a phrase, how to translate what he feels, and he can win over listeners by the sincerity of his convictions.
LEAD: Mary E. Harris, an editor, producer and director of radio and television shows for many years, died of a heart attack in her Manhattan apartment on July 19. She was 73 years old.

LEAD: The airport shop does not display every useful travel book out there with its murder mysteries; some valuable resources come from small presses or membership organizations and must be ordered in advance. Here are some of this season's helpful materials.

LEAD: G.E. is getting out of some of the businesses it has been in since it was founded. In two major deals, it agreed to sell its consumer electronics business for about $800 million to Thomson of France, which has had some troubles in that field in recent years and needs a boost. In return, Thomson will give G.E.

LEAD: THERE ARE SOME people who make entertaining a houseful of weekend guests seem no more strenuous than swinging in a hammock. A few extra people may drop in for lunch, and the table gently expands to fit them. One guest rises at 6 A.M., another at noon, and each is greeted with a hot breakfast.

LEAD: What the nation has been reading about and watching on television these last weeks is not, in the strictest sense, a Congressional investigation. Had the only purpose been to gain insights into what went wrong and to provide legislative remedies for the problem, that could easily have been done in private.
LEAD: SPOKESMEN for the state's Department of Banking and the mortgage-loan industry say they do not know how much more borrowers might have to pay in mortgage-loan fees this fall.

LEAD: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday Virginia Kathryn Boone, the daughter of Kathryn Virginia Boone of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and William Harrison Boone of Manhasset, L.I., and Stuart, Fla., was married to Andrew Arthur Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. George J. Gilbert Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Dataw Island, Beaufort, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Stacie Gilbert to Paul Joseph Wallice, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Wallice of Huntington Bay, L.I. The wedding is to be Sept. 26.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: IF THE TITLE OF BEST BRIDGE PLAYER in the world existed, the strongest claimant to it would be an easygoing, cool-eyed Texan named Robert Hamman. Over the past 10 years, Hamman has compiled the best record in the pressure-filled world of international tournament bridge. Close behind is his longtime partner and fellow Texan, Bobby Wolff.

LEAD: THE Fullerton Retirement Inn, a Spanish-style building of rental apartments in this community about an hour's drive south of Los Angeles, is the oldest of eight such complexes operated by Retirement Inns of America. It was built 10 years ago.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 24 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: After 10 years as the senior minister of the Riverside Church, the Rev. William Sloane Coffin has chosen another sort of pulpit. At services last Sunday, Dr. Coffin announced that he was resigning to become head of a Washington-based disarmament organization called SANE/Freeze. Dr. Coffin, who was outspoken in his support of civil rights and in his opposition to the Vietnam War while he was the chaplain at Yale University from 1958 to 1976, said his decision to leave Riverside had to do with ''the shadow of Doomsday.

LEAD: John R. DeLuca, vice president of health care business development for the Primerica Corporation, died of bone marrow cancer on July 18 at Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. He was 43 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

LEAD: ''Where does the North of England begin?'' I was asked the other day at a meeting in the quiet Lincolnshire town of Boston, which is itself placed uncertainly about halfway up the map, just beyond the Wash, but south of the great conurbations that lie on either side of the Pennines. None of us had an answer, though one woman declared that the North was a state of mind; if you're born with it, you can never escape.

LEAD: NOT SO LONG AGO, THE LIST of American musicans performing each year in the Soviet Union was as brief as a Russian summer. That was before a new Soviet-American cultural exchange agreement was signed in Geneva in late 1985 - and before Mikhail Gorbachev's glasnost. Now, performers are tripping over each other in their eagerness to board the bandwagon bound for Moscow, and hardly a week passes without media appearances by musicians returning from a tour of duty on the Russian front, having bathed in the enthusiasm of Soviet audiences.
LEAD: When Liz Carpenter talks, she looks at you straight in the eye and fires away in a deep Texas drawl that has roots predating the fall of the Alamo.
LEAD: A New Jersey woman was killed early yesterday when she fell or was pushed from a car after being stabbed once in the heart in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, the police said.

LEAD: ''IT ought to be a tough day today,'' Marion Berliner said to her staff at the 9 A.M. meeting. The four counselors offered no comment, but the visitor looked up from his note-jotting. Ms. Berliner addressed him. ''For folks who haven't been here before,'' she said, ''after a three-day holiday -well, Monday is bad enough, but Tuesday after a three-day holiday is worse.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last week on raising money for ''Les Miserables'' misstated the name of the attorney for Cameron Mackintosh, the show's producer. He is Paul Woerner, not Peter Woerner.

LEAD: FOR TIMOTHY DALTON, JAMES Bond is a fascinating paradox: a killer who loathes killing, a vulnerable and sensitive man-machine, an introverted extrovert, a cynical man of principle, a warm and chivalrous lover doomed to reject the women who venture into his sexual force-field. But then Timothy Dalton is a bit of a paradox himself.

LEAD: Stephanie Lynn Arlis and Rowland Brook Mayor, third-year medical students at the Jefferson Medical School and the University of Pennsylvania, respectively, were married yesterday. The Rev. George Passias performed the ceremony at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Flushing, Queens. The couple's parents are Mr.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York yesterday, Teresa Lee Marshall, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald I. Marshall of Manila, was married to Thomas Richard Watkins 3d, a son of Clare Jenkins Lambert of Washington and Mr. Watkins Jr. of New Orleans. The Rev. Timothy B. Brown performed the ceremony.
LEAD: SARTRE A Life. By Annie Cohen-Solal. Edited by Norman MacAfee. Translated by Anna Cancogni. Illustrated. 591 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24.95.

LEAD: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV has again shown his flair for the dramatic, casting himself as a dynamic leader willing to make important concessions on arms control. And with his announcement last week that the Soviet Union is prepared to accept a worldwide ban on American and Soviet medium-range and short-range missiles, Mr.
LEAD: President J. R. Jayewardene said today that he would sign an agreement here next week with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India that would end the Tamil separatist fighting.
LEAD: The crew searching for treasure from the Titanic dived to the sunken liner today in a small submarine, accompanied by a robot craft named Robin.

LEAD: Only time will tell, but give Evans and Co. an A for diligence and effort. But why wasn't the same diligence and effort there when a new general manager was picked for the Garden's other team last summer? Ranger fans have good reason to wonder. WALDO HUTCHINS 3d Glen Head, L.I.
LEAD: A FEW weeks ago, Dr. Julia Ramos-McKay's telephone rang at midnight. It was the police. They needed her help in a hostage situation.

LEAD: Peter Torres swung high on the fish-net hammock strung between the maple and butternut trees. ''Just look around,'' he said, smiling. ''No cars, no pollution, no noise.'' And then, pausing for a moment, he added, ''Why can't it be like this in the city?''

LEAD: Jaimie Leigh Spector and David J. Field are planning a December wedding, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Spector of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Field is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Field of Bala Cynwyd, Pa.
LEAD: ''THE RE-EMERGENT FIG-ure: Seven Sculptors at Storm King Art Center'' is a surprise.

LEAD: Just when they seemed to be getting it back, just when they needed to be getting it back, the old magic eluded the Mets again yesterday afternoon as they rallied twice but still lost to the Houston Astros, 7-5.

LEAD: Powerboat racing has adopted space age technology, and nowhere is that technology more likely to get a thorough testing than at the national offshore circuit's fifth competition of the season today in Atlantic City.

LEAD: Beatrice Suzanne Doering and Christopher Lane Shea, a son of Nancy Bowditch of New York and Peter L. Shea of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., plan to marry Sept. 26, the parents of the future bride, Dr. and Mrs. Eckart G. Doering of Riverside, Conn., have announced.

LEAD: Slowly, the northern cities of England are being transformed. The mills and factories, which, in the 19th century, clattered and smoked to make Britain the world's foremost industrial power, are being saved from decay to find new grandeur as industrial museums and monuments to the Industrial Revolution.
LEAD: THE PERFECT SONYA By Beverly Lowry. 242 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

LEAD: A SIGN OF THE EIGHTIES. By Gail Parent. (Putnam, $17.95.) In this bittersweet comic novel, Gail Parent displays her knack for transforming social trends into fiction. At the age of 35, Shelly Silver runs a successful upscale catering service, uses a personal shopper at Bloomingdales and sees herself as successful in every way but one: she is still single.

LEAD: Gail Vance Minor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lance Cabell Minor Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Patrick Evans Shouvlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael P. Shouvlin of New Canaan, were married yesterday at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Vincent Callahan, who was assisted by the Rev.

LEAD: WITH sidewalk chefs in their toques blanches pitching cookwear, demonstrators pushing vacuum cleaners, and a cacophony of voices hawking cheap cardigans, the scene in front of the Au Printemps department store sometimes looks like a Gallic parody of a Middle Eastern bazaar.
LEAD: MARSHALL BRICKMAN is hooked on gadgets.

LEAD: The remaking of the General Electric Company tells a story about the nation's transition to a service economy: G.E. acquired a television network not long ago, and now it will no longer make television sets - or any other consumer electronics products.

LEAD: LESS than three months after an Iraqi missile killed 37 American Navy sailors aboard the frigate Stark, the United States was plunged anew last week into a critical debate over the scope, purpose and prospects of its role in the Persian Gulf and its credibility throughout the Arab world.

LEAD: Golf Burning Up the Course: Robert Wrenn, who started play yesterday with the lowest 36-hole total on the PGA Tour this season, shot a five-under-par 67 for a six-stroke lead after three rounds of the Buick Open at Grand Blanc, Mich. Wrenn was at 21-under-par 195. Ken Green, the 1985 champion, shot 69 on the 7,014-yard Warwick Hills Golf and Country Club course and was in second place.

LEAD: The 16th show in the lobby of One Penn Plaza (33d Street and Seventh Avenue) is one of several exhibitions that have recently been organized on geometric abstraction. It is called ''Romantic Science.'' The curator is the painter and critic Stephen Westfall, one of today's most reliable guides to abstract painting.
LEAD: The Manhattan Project Starring John Lithgow, Christopher Collett, Cynthia Nixon, Jill Eikenberry, John Mahoney. Directed by Marshall Brickman. HBO Video. 120 minutes. $79.95.

LEAD: Lawrence Taylor said he got into a lot less trouble for abusing cocaine than other professional athletes who have been caught with the drug. In his forthcoming biography, ''LT: Living on the Edge,'' excerpts of which appeared last week, the star linebacker of the New York Giants said his drug use was well known during the 1985 season.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: The sound of voices singing a hymn drifts from the open windows of the plain white-frame building and out across the stillness of an August morning. A light breeze from nearby Narragansett Bay bends the tall grasses that edge the adjacent small field of weathered tombstones. Inside, sunlight streams in through the gracefully arched windows onto the bowed heads of worshipers and the bewigged head of the man in the high, wineglass pulpit, just as it must have done two and a half centuries ago when this church was new.

LEAD: THE Ford MOTOR COMPANY earned $3.3 billion last year, the fattest profit in its history, and as last week's report of $1.49 billion in second-quarter earnings indicates, is doing even better this year. General Motors Corporation had an off year in 1986, but still managed a profit of almost $3 billion and, in its second quarter this year, $977.7 million.

LEAD: International 3-19 The outlook for more contra aid has not been improved by the Iran-contra hearings, some key members of Congress say, despite the Reagan Administration's view that it has. Page 1 President Reagan was involved in a discussion last November that appeared to be intended to obscure key details of the arms sales to Iran after disclosures of the sales began to emerge, according to notes of a high-level White House meeting.

LEAD: Ayako Okamoto of Japan used her finesse with the short golf strokes to counter the thundering distance of Laura Davies on the last two holes today and gain a one-stroke lead over the English golfer going into the final round of the 42d United States Women's Open.

LEAD: The June 28 issue carried a very fine article on the progress being made with the restoration of Atlantic salmon in the Connecticut River [ '' '87 Is Termed an Upswing Year for Salmon Restoration'' ] . However, it contained one glitch. The article erroneously said that no salmon have ever reached the top of the Holyoke dam across the Connecticut River.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hodes of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Dean Hodes to Richard Hope O'Leary, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James J. O'Leary of Oyster Harbors, Mass. and John's Island, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: ''ANOTHER small farmer bankrupt.'' ''Developers gobbling up farmland.'' -Newspaper headlines, June 1987. Was all this about me? No. My farm story was different. What good memories I have. Selling fresh-picked sweet corn and other Long Island vegetables in season from a farm stand on the edge of busy Route 25A in
LEAD: Li Shiji propped his shoulder against a stone pillar that arched across the brick-lined corridor of the old Li ancestral hall.
LEAD: To the Editor: Did Virginia Van der Veer Hamilton have me in mind when she wrote ''Of Time and the Train,'' (Travel, May 31)?

LEAD: JADE AND FIRE. By Raymond Barnett. (Random House, $19.95.) It is the Peking of late 1948, the twilight of the Nationalist regime. The monks of the city's largest Taoist monastery burn their prior alive in the courtyard. Bei Menjin, chief inspector of the Peking Municipal Police, tackles the case with a briskness and authority that recalls Thatcher Colt, Anthony Abbot's police commissioner, who solved similar public crimes in 1930's New York.

LEAD: A Federal judge in Memphis has dismissed two of 11 criminal charges filed against the former Memphis State basketball coach, Dana Kirk. The charges were dismissed because of a recent ruling by the United States Supreme Court that has redrawn the legal definition of mail fraud, said United States Attorney Hickman Ewing Jr.

LEAD: THE San Francisco 49ers have fattened up considerably at wide receiver in the past two days, outbidding the Los Angeles Rams for free-agent Tony Hill only a day after trading for Johnny (Lam) Jones from the Jets. In fact, the position may be a little fatter than desirable - the Dallas Cowboys waived

LEAD: ''HERE we go, first dog of the day,'' Louie Stathopoulos said jubilantly. He flipped open a silver lid and snatched a roll. He stabbed a dog off the grill and stuffed it into the bun. After swabbing on some mustard, onions and sauerkraut, he wrapped the whole thing in a napkin and handed it over. ''O.K.,'' he said.

LEAD: Until last month, this town of 5,000 people and the paper mill that is its dominant economic force coexisted peacefully for more than 30 years. Then 1,200 paper makers at the International Paper plant walked out over a company plan to revise work rules, and the tranquillity was shattered.
LEAD: Along the edge of the north Yorkshire moors, among the beauty and seclusion of the dales, lie the sites of four abbeys that were once among the most important in England.

LEAD: THE restaurant is called Bonnies by the Bay. The bay is the Peconic and the place is the epitome of rural North Fork Long Island: the sleepy little fishing village of New Suffolk. You might expect Bonnies by the Bay to be a quaint dining spot. Not on your life! It's urbane, sophisticated and trendy.
LEAD: THE CHALLENGE By A. B. C. Whipple. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Faith Jermon St. Claire's recent article, ''Conflict of Engineering vs. Management'' [ Opinion page, June 14 ] , hit on a question that has been very much on our minds here at Union Carbide since Bhopal. Despite the fact that Bhopal was clearly a case of sabotage, probably by an employee, the tragedy also led us to re-examine the relationship between the individual engineer and our organization with regard to safety issues.

LEAD: Classical Images: A Concert in Nature New Philharmonic Masterpiece Orchestra. Kultur. 45 minutes. $29.95. Stormy surf crashing to the strains of ''Swan Lake''; icicles melting to the melodies of Mozart; ducklings paddling, in slow-motion circles, to Schumann: ''Soothing'' is the word Kultur International uses to describe this program of outdoor scenes and classical favorites.

LEAD: THE tools of their trade are ''ray'' and ''jug'' guns and stopwatches. But, unlike most scouts, Tony Marrucco of Stamford never uses the ''guns'' to calculate the velocity of a potential major league baseball prospect's fast ball.

LEAD: ALAN GREENSPAN has impeccable credentials in economics. But his talent as consensus-builder might prove to be the New York consultant's biggest asset when he takes over, as is expected, as chairman of an increasingly free-spirited Federal Reserve.
LEAD: Joint Bolivian and American efforts to combat cocaine exports have run into strong opposition in recent weeks from organized peasant growers of coca, the raw material of the drug.

LEAD: Mayor Koch petting a sow yesterday at City Hall before the filming of a segment of ''An Empire of Reason,'' a television drama on the ratification of the U.S. Constitution. The issue being filmed dealt with whether the city should have garbage collectors or continue using pigs to eat their trash. (The New York Times/Chester Higgins

LEAD: The Mets lost the pennant yesterday. Not the one that's decided in October; the one that flies on the center-field flagpole in Shea Stadium, just below the American flag. Somebody sneaked over the fence between 8 and 9 o'clock yesterday morning, lowered the pennant and took it away.
LEAD: Robert Wrenn finished with a near-record 26-under-par 262 today for his first PGA Tour victory in the $600,000 Buick Open at Warwick Hills Golf and Country Club.
LEAD: An unheralded foursome snatched a victory here Saturday night in one of the most exciting Spingold Knockout finals in the event's 63-year history.

LEAD: In this bucolic little town where one Abner Doubleday did not invent baseball, and where a lovely piece of fiction was allowed to grow into a legend, three men who performed real, and extraordinary deeds, were officially proclaimed here today as legends themselves.

LEAD: Jane Linda Baker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Baker of Demarest, N.J., and H. Roger Segelken, a son of Mrs. H. Clifford Segelken of Phoenicia, N.Y., and the late Mr. Segelken, were married yesterday at Shotwell Memorial Park in Skaneateles, N.Y., by Linda Lavery, a justice of the peace. The bride, a former reporter for The Syracuse Herald Journal, graduated from Syracuse University and is a freelance writer.
LEAD: THE EUROPEAN TRIBE. By Caryl Phillips. 129 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.
LEAD: George O'Day, a sailboat designer and racer who captured an Olympic gold medal in yachting, died of colon cancer today. He was 64 years old.

LEAD: A QUICK flick through magazines, a brief glance around the street or a short walk through a hair salon confirms that once again longer hair is ''in'' for women. Most men insist it never should have gone out. If hair, as psychologists say, is a medium of communication between the sexes, then a woman's longer hair may ease the introductions.

LEAD: By some measures, Massachusetts has the strongest economy in the country and the strongest housing market. As a result, according to state officials, it also has one of the biggest housing shortages for low-income families.
LEAD: The Perrier Group has assigned three of its regional bottled water brands to Altschiller Reitzfeld. Billings could reach $4 million, trade sources indicate.

LEAD: Similar events for Presidential candidates have been dubbed ''cattle shows.'' For candidates running for boroughwide office in the Bronx, an appearance yesterday on the steps of the county building before a coalition of church groups was termed an ''accountability assembly.''

LEAD: Still badly shaken by the defection two months ago of a hero air force general, President Fidel Castro tonight lashed out at ''miserable and repugnant traitors'' who, he said, betray the Cuban revolution.

LEAD: The two weeks of competition are expected to be stirring, and the daily opportunities for promoting international understanding will be extensive. But when more than 4,000 athletes from 38 nations gather for the closing ceremonies of the 10th Pan American Games in Indianapolis Aug. 23, there will be a reminder that all is not sweetness and light in the

LEAD: Immense concentrations of mass that appear to be black holes, each with the gravity of 10 million to 100 million suns, have been detected at the cores of the two spiral galaxies closest to ours, astronomers announced yesterday.
LEAD: A Manhattan man was charged with first-degree manslaughter yesterday in connection with the beating death of his wife in a midtown hotel room, the police said.

LEAD: Like it or not, Britain's chief delegate to the United Nations will be dining this week at his Beekman Place residence on sheep sorrel, lady's-thumb, poor man's pepper, amaranth and lamb's-quarters - all wild plants and weeds picked yesterday in Central Park by his enterprising chef.

LEAD: THE first Family Circle ad campaign from Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton breaks today in the trade press, showing off a new theme line: ''For the Women of Today Raising the Generation of Tomorrow.''
LEAD: A jury awarded a family $380,000 Thursday after a cemetery mix-up separated a couple who had wanted to be buried next to each other.

LEAD: Brenda Marie Mendoza, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Radames Mendoza of San Juan, P. R., and Jonathan Roy Friedman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Friedman of New York, were married yesterday at the Hotel Casa Madrona in Sausalito, Calif., by Rabbi Jonathan Plaut.

LEAD: Glenn Evans had drunk five, maybe six bottles of beer when he slipped behind the wheel of his 1971 Plymouth Duster and set off with three teen-age girls for a drive one hot August night last year.

LEAD: The two agencies in the finals for the $150 million Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. account expect to learn of the winner on Friday. Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago, is presenting on Wednesday, and Chiat/Day, Los Angeles, on Thursday. The previous agency was the William Esty Company.
LEAD: Nearly 10 years after Wang Laboratories Inc. pulled out of South Africa, the company's computers are still widely available.
LEAD: The collective bargaining that begins today between the United Automobile Workers and General Motors and the Ford Motor Company could be the most critical labor talks in the last half century.
LEAD: Smoking also figured in a debate in the House of Representatives last week over an $11 billion spending bill that covers the Department of Transportation.

LEAD: Julie Hartenstein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hans Hartenstein of Syracuse, was married yesterday to Jonathan W. Meyersohn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rolf Meyersohn of New York. Judge Minna Buck of Family Court in Syracuse officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

LEAD: New orders for American-made machine tools rose 9.4 percent in June, after strongly encouraging increases in May, and shipments increased 11.9 percent, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: With his first collection under his own name, Christian Lacroix has been catapulted into fashion's hall of fame. Like Christian Dior exactly 40 years ago, he has revived a failing institution, the haute couture, or made-to-order branch of French fashion. He has done it with verve, whimsy and a youthful air.

LEAD: MacNamara, Clapp & Klein will announce today that Jeffrey W. Clapp, its 49-year-old chairman, is resigning from the six-year-old agency to pursue other, unidentified goals. An alumnus of both Norman, Craig & Kummel and Ted Bates & Company, he was the $42 million agency's top account man.

LEAD: Efforts to fight a blaze in a high-rise Harlem apartment building that killed seven people in March were hampered by fire dispatchers who mishandled calls and by firefighters at the scene who created an atmosphere of confusion, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

LEAD: The sun was shining on the South Side this afternoon. Saturday's oppressive heat was gone, and a comfortable breeze was blowing, and the White Sox were threatening to remove the Yankees from first place.
LEAD: Two weeks after 174 Indian nationals landed in Nova Scotia from a freighter, all but nine have been approved for temporary residence in Canada.

LEAD: Marie Daly Price and Robert Wilson Crandall Jr. were married yesterday at the Warren, Vt., home of the bridegroom's mother, Mrs. Crandall, who also lives in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. David Geib, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mr. Crandall's father is deceased.

LEAD: When a Police Commissioner publicly blames most of the city's crime on an ethnic, racial or religious group, he had better be right.

LEAD: A police scuba team yesterday recovered the bodies of two men who apparently drowned during a futile effort to rescue an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy who had fallen into Coney Island Creek Saturday afternoon, the police said.

LEAD: An Associated Press dispatch Friday from Santa Ana, Calif., about a bias lawsuit filed by a policeman, misidentified the group that the jury found had discriminated. It was the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California, not the national organization.
LEAD: QUESTION: What's the best season record for a major league team that failed to win a pennant or a division title?

LEAD: In his fourth full season with the Yankees, Don Mattingly has already made it to Cooperstown. Then, again, all the Yankees will be there today when they play the Atlanta Braves in the Hall of Fame exhibition game at 9,980-seat Doubleday Field.

LEAD: Fifty percent against the Administration's policy toward Nicaragua, and about 25 percent in favor - that's been roughly the public opinion scorecard for years. Now, after the emotional pleas of Lieut. Col. Oliver North, there's been an evening out. It's probably a blip. But what if the surge in support for the Nicaraguan rebels holds?

LEAD: First for Piquet: Nelson Piquet of Brazil, driving a Williams-Honda, won the West German Grand Prix yesterday in Hockenheim. It was his first victory of the season. Piquet now has a 4-point lead in the Formula One world championship drivers' standing with 39 points. Stefan Johansson of Sweden finished in second place, and Aryton Senna of Brazil took third.

LEAD: When Albert Einstein lay dying in Princeton Hospital, the nurse assigned to him spoke no German and the great physicist's last words passed uncomprehended. Strangely, for a person of such interest and eminence, the rest of his legacy has long remained almost equally inaccessible. Publication of his papers has begun only now, after a 30-year delay, and even then with an English translation supplied as a grudging afterthought.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Robert H. Bork's role as Acting Attorney General in the Watergate scandals misidentified the wife of Ralph K. Winter, a Federal judge who was then a Yale Law School professor. Mr. Winter's wife is Kathryn Winter. At the time Mr. Bork was married to Claire Bork, who died in 1980.

LEAD: After screaming about being priced out of markets when the dollar soared in the first half of the decade, companies across the United States are beginning to see its decline translate into healthier earnings.

LEAD: It is perhaps a tribute to the spirit of democracy in New York State that when the Assembly opened its chamber to the public this weekend for an open debate, many participants did not hesitate to use their time at the microphone to condemn their hosts.

LEAD: The Federal Government's first compilation of occupational deaths in the United States has found that mining and construction jobs are the riskiest.

LEAD: There was a price to be paid - thunderstorms and some power failures -but the heat wave that grilled the New York region with 90-degree temperatures and worse for nine straight days came to an abrupt, and merciful, end yesterday.

LEAD: Carl D. Newton 3d, who is waiting to complete his purchase of the Fox Photo retail unit from the Eastman Kodak Company, says that the decision to buy the stores was based on more than just business.

LEAD: The cost of a stay in a New Jersey hospital was 13 percent less than the national average in 1985, and the state showed the lowest five-year increase in daily Medicare charges, according to a New Jersey Hospital Association report.

LEAD: WHEN Pam Postema dresses for work, she changes her clothes in a corner of a concrete locker room shared by three male co-workers. LEAD: Pat Ryan, the aggressive veteran the Jets trusted to start last season's two playoff games, insisted today that the absent Ken O'Brien still is the club's No. 1 quarterback.

LEAD: When the Giants open their training camp here Monday at Pace University's Westchester campus, most of their 14 drafted rookies will probably be on hand, their contracts signed. Rookies and veterans alike must be signed to take part in training camp.

LEAD: With a parade, prayers and speeches by politicians, the Salvation Army opened an $8 million community center in Harlem yesterday, ending a 14-year struggle with community residents who favored the construction of housing at the site.

LEAD: Harry H. Wellington, professor and former dean at Yale Law School, longtime faculty colleague and next-door neighbor here of Robert H. Bork, recalled the day he heard of his friend's nomination to the Supreme Court.
LEAD: French explorers today retrieved dishes from the wreckage of the Titanic, the first objects ever recovered from the luxury ocean liner that sank 75 years ago, killing 1,513 passengers.

LEAD: Protesting what they called the stagnant state of rock-and-roll radio in New York City, a group of gadfly radio enthusiasts took to the airwaves last week from a rusty old freighter anchored five miles off Long Island's South Shore.

LEAD: Only weeks after major banks in the United States declared that a quarter of their Latin American loans were probably worthless, Brazil has asked its bank creditors for $7.2 billion in new money at zero interest.
LEAD: Capping a remarkable comeback year, Stephen Roche swept into Paris today as the winner of the Tour de France bicycle race.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration found itself handicapped today by the death of Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige at a time when it is trying to work with Congress on critical trade legislation.

LEAD: Charles Dutoit is not a hard-driving conductor. His reputation, considerable and still growing, is based in good part on performances of the big orchestral showpieces - in particular a series of sonically and instrumentally brilliant compact disks on the London label with his Montreal Symphony. But a great part of his appeal stems from the fact that he plays the blockbusters for their musical values, naturally, with blockbusting as an exciting but natural byproduct.

LEAD: Beth Ellen Goldstein, who will enroll in the M.B.A. program at Fordham University in September, and Neil Jay Weissman, a fourth-year medical student at the Cornell University Medical College, were married yesterday at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I. LEAD: It is reckoning time in both the Congress and the Reagan Administration for the most far-reaching banking legislation in more than seven years.

LEAD: Law-enforcement officers in riot gear used tear gas to break up a disturbance early today after 1,500 to 2,000 youths, in town to watch hydroplane races, began throwing bottles and rocks at police officers.

LEAD: THE William Herbert Hunt trust estate, the largest privately held trust to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, has repeatedly used extraordinary legal tactics. The reorganization plan filed last Wednesday by the trust's attorneys was more of the same, according to lawyers involved in the case.

LEAD: The July issue of posh Architectural Digest magazine went on sale June 10 with a special insert from Rolls-Royce that had a leathery look to carry its leathery smell. That's right, with the help of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, the magazine published a scent strip with the smell of a new Rolls at a cost of about $125,000.
LEAD: ''Shalom, Shamir'' chanted African dancers as the Israeli Star of David fluttered alongside the green-red-and-yellow flag of this West African nation.

LEAD: Billy Joel brought his rock-and-roll here today and won the souls of those in a stony Soviet audience, leaving them cheering, dancing on chairs and looking around in fearful wonder as they followed the music and not the rules.

LEAD: The testimony of Secretary of State George P. Shultz last week and documents offered as evidence in the Iran-contra hearings provide a backstage look at why President Reagan made misleading statements about the Iran arms sales soon after they were disclosed.

LEAD: Policemen holding back demonstrators outside Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's residence in New Delhi. The protesters, from a right-wing opposition group, said they were demonstrating against reported corruption in the Gandhi Government and attacks on politicians opposed to the Prime Minister. (AP)
LEAD: An airplane carrying Governor Cuomo made an emergency landing on one engine today after a warning light indicated the other engine was on fire.

LEAD: In December 1985 and again in August 1986, the municipal bond market was the scene of frantic deal-making, as bond attorneys and securities dealers worked around the clock with local government officials to complete financings that would soon be banned by changes in Federal tax laws.

LEAD: A popular thing for tourists to do in the capital is have their picture taken next to a life-sized cardboard cutout of President Reagan. This week, a cardboard rival appeared on the Pennsylvania Avenue sidewalks in front of the White House: a 6-foot-tall portrait of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, all sparkling medals and square shoulders.

LEAD: One person on Capitol Hill gets to share the Congressional doorkeepers' chairs outside the House of Representatives chambers, a good spot to catch the eye of an arriving or departing member of Congress. Evelyn Dubrow and no one else. No one protests. This 4-foot 11-inch lobbyist for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union who began roaming the halls of Congress 29 years ago seeking support for a $1 minimum wage, and who still troops Capitol Hill in her size 4 shoes, has earned the privilege.

LEAD: After John McEnroe produced a breezy singles victory that put the United States team into a tie with West Germany in the Davis Cup relegation round, it was left to Tim Mayotte to conquer Boris Becker to complete the comeback needed to keep the United States in contention for the 1988 cup.

LEAD: As they had promised they would, the Association of National Advertisers went to Circuit Court in Tallahassee, Fla., on Friday to challenge the constitutionality of Florida's 5 percent sales and use tax on advertising, which went into effect July 1. The complaint cites the state Constitution on free speech guarantees and the United States Constitution on its free speech, commerce and due process clauses.

LEAD: These days, when Kim Dae Jung takes an afternoon nap as his driver goes along the Han River here, the road behind him is clear.

LEAD: When a fire broke out in a neighborhood he was visiting, Mayor Raymond Flynn raced to the scene ahead of the firefighters, kicked his way into a burning house and helped an elderly, handicapped man to safety.

LEAD: By now, most residents here are accustomed to restrictions on wood-burning stoves, tough standards on automobile emissions and other measures of recent years to control the severe air pollution along the eastern slope of the Rocky Mountains.

LEAD: A secret airlift of American arms to Angolan guerrillas continues through southern Zaire, two Western diplomats stationed in Zaire said today.

LEAD: Dick Wellstood, one of the younger jazzmen who kept the traditions alive in the years after World War II, died of heart failure Friday in Palo Alto, Calif., where he went to attend the Peninsula Jazz Party. He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The surging market for homes in the suburbs of New York City has abruptly shifted gears. In many suburban communities, where real-estate prices have more than doubled since 1980, industry experts say there is a huge inventory of unsold homes, and a sudden paucity of buyers.

LEAD: Camco Inc., a leading maker of oil production equipment, said yesterday that it would be taken private in a $29-a-share tender offer by Pearson Inc., the United States subsidiary of Pearson P.L.C. of Britain.

LEAD: Charles Stark Draper, a pioneer in advanced guidance technology for aircraft and missiles and developer of the navigation system that steered Americans to the moon and back, died Saturday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 85 years old.
LEAD: A man in a sports car fired a gun at a pickup truck in heavy traffic today in the latest of eight highway shootings that have left two people dead and one critically wounded this summer.

LEAD: It was Mookie Wilson's turn to conduct one of those summer sports clinics for New York youngsters, but when the Mets' outfielder got to the gym in the basement of a Bronx school one day last week, instead of facing a group of 150 budding baseball players eager for instruction, he found himself surrounded by a horde of pubescent news hounds on the scent of a scoop.

LEAD: Although trade is hardly ever mentioned when poll takers ask Americans to name the nation's most important problem, it has emerged as the first issue to rouse serious debate among the 1988 Presidential contenders.

LEAD: A convicted rapist and kidnapper, released from prison two months ago, was charged yesterday with 3 of 13 sexual assaults on women that have stirred fear and anger in Central Queens, the police said.

LEAD: The Salt Lake Trappers, an independent collection of players rebuffed by the major leagues, continued to add to the longest winning streak in professional baseball history today by beating Pocatello, 8-6, for their 29th straight victory.

LEAD: Two years ago, India's premier stock exchange here was swept by an unprecedented buying boom. Hundreds of thousands of new investors flooded the market as public enthusiasm grew for the liberal and pro-business policies of the new Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi.

LEAD: The Bolshoi Ballet and Red Army Chorus have scheduled performances in Israel, it was announced today. Their appearance would mark a significant upgrading of Soviet-Israeli cultural ties.

LEAD: The monsoon rains are at their most pitiless now in Bangladesh, a country regularly victimized by wind and water.

LEAD: A member of the Danish national skydiving team plunged to his death Saturday after being knocked unconscious in an aerial collision with another skydiver. LEAD: ''Independent Arts,'' an exhibition of work by seven artists associated with the Queens Independent Living Center is to go on display Thursday at the Cork Gallery, at Lincoln Center. The gallery, which is accessible to physically handicapped people, is on the lower concourse level of Avery Fisher Hall, Broadway and 65th Street.

LEAD: Jim Bishop, a reporter and columnist who wrote his way onto the best-seller lists with his hour-by-hour formula and you-are-there style, died Sunday of respiratory failure at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old.

LEAD: Tennis Czechoslovakia Advances: Hana Mandlikova and Helena Sukova won their singles matches yesterday as second-seeded Czechoslovakia defeated Sweden to advance to the second round of the Federation Cup women's team championship in Vancouver, British Columbia. Mandlikova, coming back after a foot injury that forced her to miss Wimbledon, defeated Caterina Lindqvist, 6-3, 6-2, after Sukova won against Carina Karlsson 6-4, 6-4.

LEAD: William Faulkner worked on 17 film scripts in the 30's and 40's -originals, adaptations and collaborations with more seasoned screenwriters. His Hollywood output added up to 2,500 typescript pages - the length of a very thick, unwritten novel.

LEAD: O'Connell Street, the most famous thoroughfare in Dublin, was packed yesterday as an estimated quarter of a million people welcomed home Stephen Roche, the first Irishman ever to win the Tour de France bicycle race. The 27-year-old Roche, who beat Pedro Delgado of Spain by 40 seconds, was driven - on four wheels -through the Irish capital, his native city.
LEAD: A Board of Education program that promised summer jobs to 3,500 New York City students has placed only several hundred of them.

LEAD: The Federal Government has reversed itself and will automatically extend Social Security disability payments to victims of AIDS who meet the newly expanded Federal definition of the deadly disease, a top Social Security Administration official said yesterday.

LEAD: The Stride Rite Corporation, which makes children's shoes, has elected Michael W. Rayden president and chief operating officer, effective next Monday.

LEAD: Leaders of the House Agriculture Committee plan to introduce legislation this week that would provide a multibillion-dollar line of credit with the Treasury to rescue the crippled Farm Credit System, committee staff members said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Motorists here, displaying hair-trigger impulses reminiscent of the frontier West, have tangled with each other in a string of highway shootings that have left two people dead and four injured over the past five weeks.

LEAD: THE profusion of graphics software on the market today has made the creation of visuals a breeze. But that does not mean that the flood of graphs and charts being churned out by home computers are good visuals. In fact, many of them are downright confusing.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company plans to retool its tractor plant in Romeo, Mich., to produce new engines by mid-1990. Ford has completed feasibility studies on the project, expected to cost more than $900 million, and will begin conversion of the 1.4-million-square-foot plant in mid-1988, a Ford executive said.

LEAD: When the Giants opened training camp yesterday, only the rookies and the quarterbacks and a few other players were there. The entire squad isn't due to report to Pace University in Pleasantville, N.Y., until Friday when all the Giants' authors will be in uniform before any of their books are in the stalls.

LEAD: Influenza impairs a driver's reaction time even more than does a ''moderate'' dose of alcohol, according to a group of British researchers.

LEAD: For most of its 23 years, the Museum of African Art has lived a stepchild's existence among the grand museums of Washington, making do in a row of nine town houses on Capitol Hill, a few blocks behind the Supreme Court.

LEAD: Dr. Donald R. Cressey, one of the nation's leading experts on the sociology of crime, died July 21 in Solvang, Calif. He was 68 years old. As a professor of sociology at the University of California at Santa Barbara for 26 years, Dr. Cressey wrote several highly regarded books on the causes and prevention of crime.
LEAD: A month of movies:

LEAD: T. Allan McArtor was sworn in today as chief of the Federal Aviation Administration and promised to take steps designed to reduce delays and improve safety. Mr. McArtor, 45 years old, who had been a senior vice president for Federal Express, issued a warning to airline employees. ''Pilots, co-pilots, flight engineers and other crew members are also on notice,'' he said.

LEAD: ''CRISIS ON FEDERAL STREET'' opens and closes with the same aerial picture: a look north toward downtown Chicago from an enormous housing project only five miles away. The camera makes it appear, though, that these are two separate cities, with a great plain in between. The view may be distorted, but it is not necessarily untrue.
LEAD: John C. Sacco, a composer and conductor, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Malcolm Baldrige, the Secretary of Commerce, who died in a rodeo accident Saturday, brought decency and a cool head to the upper reaches of politics. In an Administration often marred by zealotry, he stood for soft-spoken reason.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Jose DeLeon, a pitcher for the Chicago White Sox, suffered slight injuries to his jaw and back in a traffic accident yesterday and missed his starting assignment last night at Tiger Stadium in Detroit. DeLeon was treated at Hinsdale Hospital in Chicago and released yesterday afternoon, said Stuart Wade, a White Sox spokesman.

LEAD: The sprinkler system in a Harlem apartment tower had not been working for at least several months and possibly years before a fire that killed seven people on March 22, the head of a special Fire Department inquiry said yesterday.

LEAD: Bill Madlock's eighth-inning single scored Tom Brookens with the tie-breaking run as the Detroit Tigers beat the Chicago White Sox, 4-1, tonight and moved within a half game of the Yankees in the American League East.
LEAD: The stock market continued to regain the ground it lost early last week, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.61 points, to 2,493.94.

LEAD: Edward J. Mortola, the Chancellor of Pace University, has taken over as chairman of the Lincoln Center Institute, the educational arm of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. He replaces Francis Keppel, who retired from the post last month and who is to serve as chairman emeritus of the institute's board.

LEAD: The Walt Disney Company said that a new 100,000-square-foot exhibit, billed as a ride through the human body, would open at the Epcot Center Disney World in Orlando, Fla., by 1989. The company declined to disclose figures, but said the exhibit would be the most expensive ever built at the center. The exhibit is similar to ''Star Tours,'' a $32 million attraction that opened this year at Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif.

LEAD: David Robinson, the all-America center from Navy, will lead the United States Pan American Games team in its first exhibition game against a squad of National Basketball Association players tonight at Market Square Arena in Indianapolis. Besides Robinson, the United States team includes Dean Garrett and Keith Smart of Indiana, the National Collegiate Athletic Association champion, Rex Chapman of Kentucky, Jeff Lebo of North Carolina, Fennis Dembo of Wyoming and Danny Manning of Kansas.

LEAD: SALZBURG, Austria, July 27 -In a year when all the world is celebrating the 200th anniversary of ''Don Giovanni,'' sometimes in distressingly cavalier if not actually criminal ways, Mozart's hometown could hardly overlook the opportunity to pay the respect it neglected to give the opera in the composer's lifetime.

LEAD: A company that New York City helped establish to make concrete at lower prices produced its first 100 cubic yards of concrete yesterday. In doing so, the company averted a threat from Mayor Koch to cancel its contract for failure to operate.

LEAD: A survivor of the Titanic sinking said today that salvagers were greedy ''vultures'' for taking artifacts from the wreck, which became a grave for her father and 1,512 other people 75 years ago.

LEAD: Despite all reports that President Reagan and Judge Robert H. Bork, his choice for the Supreme Court vacancy, are political and ideological soul mates, the two scarcely know each other. LEAD: The top problem in the National Football League is alcohol abuse rather than drug abuse, according to Mike Lynn, the general manager of the Minnesota Vikings, whose quarterback, Tommy Kramer, is undergoing treatment for alcohol abuse. After being charged with drunken driving last Friday night, Kramer entered the Hazelden Foundation in Center City, Minn., Sunday to begin 28 days of rehabilitation, his second stay in a treatment center in five years.

LEAD: The people of Panama gave a clear cry for freedom yesterday in a nationwide general strike. The strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, seeing it coming, acted brutally to snuff it out. He closed the opposition newspapers hours before the strike. Then his troops stormed the home of the army officer who had fingered him as the architect of a series of murders and frauds, and arrested the renegade colonel.

LEAD: University of Texas officials have decided to declare James Lott, a defensive back, ineligible for his senior season for accepting money from two New York agents, Lloyd Bloom and Norby Walters, The Atlanta Journal reported yesterday. LEAD: In different ways, two major designers electrified their audiences Monday as the fall and winter couture openings reached the halfway mark. LEAD: A Coast Guardsman jumping 30 feet from a helicopter into the Atlantic near Jacob Riis Park in Queens yesterday during an annual wet drill. The drill, a test of water-survival skills, involves jumping from a copter, swimming to a raft and paddling it to a waiting boat. About 40 guardsmen from the Coast Guard air station at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn participated in the exercise.

LEAD: ''SINGING ON THE TREADMILL'' is a frolic with an edge - which may be why it was banned by the Hungarian authorities for a decade after it was made in 1974. LEAD: FILL a bathtub with holy water and garlic, load a plastic water pistol and aim at the vampires. These lost boys are not Peter-Pan innocents, but teen-agers who dress like rock stars, roar through town on motorcycles and happen to fly through the air and drink blood.

LEAD: A RELUCTANT HERO. By Francoise Sagan. Translated by Christine Donougher. (Dutton, $16.95.) France, May 1942. Beautiful, troubled Alice and her resolute Resistance lover, Jerome, descend on the peaceful country estate of Jerome's boyhood best friend, the happy industrialist Charles Sambrat. Their intention: to persuade Charles to let them use his property in the unoccupied Dauphine as a way station for Jews being smuggled out of France.

LEAD: Trail Blazers, a New York-based social service agency for disadvantaged children, will celebrate its 100th anniversary at noon tomorrow by erecting a teepee near the Bethesda Fountain in Central Park.
